text: The familiar checkerboard "Brady" blue, just as we oneys saw at the beginning of the television show. CAROL, MARCIA, JAN, CINDY, all pop onto the screen; then MIKE, GREG, PETER, BOBBY, pop onto the screen, and we are amazed at the similarity of the new Bradys to the origina Bradys. Mike and Greg sport the 1970’s big curly hair, and Peter and Bobby’s hair is long, too. Carol has her fli which all America remembers. Marcia and Jan have their beautiful long hair as before, and Cindy "the youngest one in curls". Jan wears glasses as she did in the later episodes. As the theme continues they all look around in every direction. Then ALICE, in her unremovable blue uniform, takes her place in the center box just as the theme ends. :

The very familiar Brady house in all its suburban glory. INT. BOYS’ BEDROOM - DAY - CLOSE ANGLE - BATHROOM DOOR Greg’s fist pounds on the door, and WE PULL BACK AND WIDE to see the frustrated Greg, Peter, and Bobby -- as well as the familiar bunk bedded boys’ bedroom. The boys are in robes and pajamas. _
Marcia, will you come out of there? We have to get ready to rehearse!
Yeah! Stop brushing your hair!

Marcia, I’ve got to go! INT. KIDS’ BATHROOM MARCIA . . Sixty-three, sixty-four, sixty- five... INT. GIRLS’ BEDROOM on this side of the door, Jan and Cindy -- in pajamas -- are equally antsy and huddled at the door.
We want to get in there, Marcia. We've got hair, too, you know. Cindy pulls her own trademark pigtails in opposite directions.
(fluffing her curls) I’ve got hair on both sides. INT. KIDS’ BATHROOM
Seventy-two, seventy-three, seventy-four... INT. BOYS’ BEDROOM Bobby is dancing from one foot to another foot. Greg sees Bobby’s dam is about to burst. Bobby starts toward the window.
Bobby, not out the window! cuT TO

(NOTE: A word about the backyard: it’s exactly the same as the Brady yard we remember. Except it’s real grass instead of articial turf; a real backyard.) In addition to the usual Brady objects in the backyard, the yard is cluttered with remnants of various episodes; a teeter-totter, Greg's surfboard, a club house, and, of course, Tiger’s doghouse. TIGER, who had been lost after the first-season’s episodes, has found his way back home for this film. One major addition has been made to the backyard. It’s a practice platform for the Brady kids to rehearse their song and dance numbers. _ It’s about a foot high and ten by six, with different size circular platforms for each of the kids to stand on.
As all six Brady kids stream out‘of the family room now dressed in regular 1973 clothes; bellbottom pants, mini-skirts, etc. They are jabbering excitedly as they head for the rehearsal platform.
Pete, punch the button, Peter crosses to a tape recorder (1973 version) and start the music accompaniment. Then he quickly hops up on the platform with the rest of the kids as the music starts.
OPENING CREDITS roll as the Brady kids rehearse the numbe They each have half a jump rope to simulate a mike and cord. Jan sings the lead.
As the music ends, Greg shuts off the tape recorder.
There! I did the lead, and I Was really good.
Yeah, but we’re not doing that song in the contest. We’re doing "Good Time Music".
(snidely) Oh, where you and Marcia have the lead.
That’s right, Jan.
That’s how it always is. Marcia sings the lead vocal. Marcia gets the lead in the school play. Marcia gets a new boyfriend. Marcia, Marcia, Marcia!
Jan, cheer up. They’re not letting me sing lead vocal either.
That’s because we want to win. Your voice cracks like a broken mirror.’
Marcia sings an impression of Peter’s voice cracking in "Time to Change".
MARCIA “ (singing and cracking) When it’s time to change, then it’s time to change...
Look who thinks she’s a prima dona.
What’s a prima dona?

{not knowing either) Everybody knows what a prima dona is. Don’t you know anything, Cindy? CINDY n Sure. I know that you -don’t know what a prima dona is either. Cindy sticks her tongue out at him. Meanwhile: _
Look, this is the amateur finals at the Hollywood Bowl. And we have to win first prize. We’ve got to put our best face forward.
What’s the matter with my face?

Would you like that in alphabetical order? Jan flies at Marcia and grabs her hair and starts to pull In return, Marcia grabs Jan’s hair, and starts to pull. There’s a lot of yelling as Greg and Peter try to pull th girls apart.
Carol and Alice are at the stove in the good old orange and olive colored kitchen, circa 1973. They can see the backyard through the windows in the den. They can also hear the racket.
ALICE a Re Doesn’t sound much like music to me, . Mrs. Brady.
I'd better go out there, and put some harmony into the act. As Alice stirs something on the stove, Carol strides “!* purposefully to the backyard.
As Carol enters, and moves quickly toward Jan and Marcia, who are still tugging at each other’s hair. Carol gets between them.
Girls, cut this out! As the girls separate:
Jan started it. a
No, I didn’t. Marcia started it. The . day I was born. BS
We're Bradys. Bradys don’t fight with each other. a Those are magic words.
(contritely) Sorry, Mom.
Now why don’t you change into your -regular clothes, so you’1ll be ready for dinner when Dad gets home? Now that order has been restored, Carol returns to the house.

Taking a look around. It’s exactly as remembered, from a the open-stepped stairway to the ceramic horse. Carol is in the alcove at the dining room table and is fluffing up the floral centerpiece -- one of her primary occupations.
Mike enters with his briefcase and calls out the expected...
Hi, Honey, I’m home.
Perking up at the news, she meets him in the center of th room. She kisses him. He savors it.
(continuing) With greetings like that, I should stop Sy by two or three times a: day.
Just what I told the milkman. They share a laugh. Mike puts down his briefcase.
Well, which one of the kids needs a lecture?
How’d you guess?
No guess. Between us, we’ve got six kids. Somebody always needs a lecture. CAROL ° Jan. po “MIKE Marcia, Marcia, Marcia?

(confirming) Marcia, Marcia, Marcia. FLIP TO o  INT. MIKE’S DEN - NIGHT The small room just off the living room. It’s down three steps to the loveseat and drafting table. It’s the Brady equivalent of the wood shed. Jan is hearing it from Mike and Carol.
Marcia, Marcia, Marcia. That’s all I hear. It’s enough to make me puke.
Bradys don’t talk like that.
Sorry, Dad, but it’s just not fair. She’s got pretty hair, and a pretty face. I’ve got glasses and braces.
You’ve also got a family that loves you.
Big wow.
Jan, right now Marcia seems to have it all. :
That’s right, sweetheart. Your turn will come.
That’s what you’ve been telling me since I was two.
You just have to be patient. There’s an old Chinese proverb, "Patience is the greatest virtue".
Yeah? Well, I’m sick of being virtuous, too. With that, Jan storms out of the roon.
I know just how she feels. When I was a little girl, I felt the same way about my sister.
You don’t have a sister.
Not anymore. I killed her. i Mike hits her with a sofa pillow. cuT TO |

head_text.subj: CAMERA ZEROES IN ON OUTSIDE PRISON WALL AND DIRT AREA

text: CAMERA MOVES IN FURTHER TO SHOW there is movement in the dirt. Then more movement. Then the dirt seems to be falling back into the prison. Then we see a big kitchen spoon. Then the hand holding the spoon. The hand has a distinctive tattoo with the numbers: 1,2,3, hand etched. WIDER SHOT - CAMERA MOVES WIDER © as the crewcutted ROCKY pulls himself out of the hole int freedom outside the prison wall. He is dressed in traditional prison clothes. Then CLARENCE, a huge Black convict, emerges after Rocky.
SCREECHING UP in a 1964 Valiant is Rocky’s nineteen year old son, JUNIOR. Barely slowing down, Junior opens up the passenger side door. :
Let’s go, Dad. Then Junior sees Clarence. JUNIOR a (continuing) . Who's he?
Never mind. Let’s move it. Rocky and Clarence jump in. As the car speeds away, SIREN GO OFF in the prison, and searchlights scan the area. cuT TO
You never said there’d be two of you.
Clarence was my cellmate. And he deserved a break today. Clarence doesn’t say anything. He has a hulking presence and rarely speaks.
(continuing) You bring everything? Junior hands Rocky a package. He opens it and takes out two guns and a six pack of beer.
There it is, Dad. One six pack and two guns. I guess the other gun is for Clarence.
Good guess, kid. Rocky realizes which car they're in.
_ (continuing) This is the car I bought you, ain’t it
Yeah.
Very smart. Busting me out in your own car. They’1ll tag us for sure. :
I don’t have much experience driving a getaway car. Okay?
Just drive, smart ass. Junior turns from his father and speeds along faster. cuT TO
A black and white is parked. TWO POLICEMEN are leaning back, relaxing, their hats pushed back.
Finally, a few minutes » ‘to relax. CoP #2 Yeah. It’s been a rough night.

All units, be on the lookout for an escaped prisoner, Rocky Portugal. He is believed to be armed and dangerous and in his son’s blue Valiant, license plate MRT 874 and traveling west from Chino. Escaping with Portugal is Clarence Dawkins, former bodyguard to crime kingpin, Willy the Mongoose.
Can‘’t guys bust out in the morning?
The Valiant screams down the street and passes the cop ca
The cops can’t believe that it’s the escape vehicle.
MRT 874! Thar she blows.
MUSIC: HARD DRIVING 1970’S SONG ("BORN TO BE WILD"

Junior is a good driver and manages to elude the cops. He cuts off a car, and makes a hard left onto the Santa Monica Freeway heading west to the Pacific Coast Highway. Then under the overpass and onto the coast route itself. The cops come alongside, but Junior uses a moving van as interference to lose them as the pursuers go up the coast and Junior speeds up the ramp. cuUT TO
Well, we lost them.
Like hell! We better blow off this bus. Rocky sees a cliff to the side.
(continuing) Pull over. Junior does so. Then the boy sees the cliff and understands his father’s plan.
Come on, Dad. The car’s got sentimental value.
Just get out. If you can’t say goodbye to your wheels, leave the drivin’ to me. Clarence gets out. Then Junior gets out. Rocky hands his son the beer and guns.

Rocky steps on the gas, and careens toward the cliff. Jus before the car goes over, Rocky bails out and tumbles to the ground. The car sails through the air then smashes t9 the ground where it breaks apart and bursts into flames.
Rocky gets up and dusts himself off as Junior walks up to him. Junior looks distraught.
He smiles as he enjoys watching the car explode. .
Rocky takes back the guns and beer.
Don’t be getting teary, Junior. As long as we got guns, we can always get another car.
we 12
I had some books and drawings in the back seat. Rocky takes a folded map from his pocket.

The only drawing you ever made worth spit was this map of the prison. you got every one of them pipes and wires in the right place, or me and Clarence never coulda dug our way out. Clarence joins them.
(continuing) Right, Clarence? Clarence nods. Rocky pockets the drawing and starts off down the street. Junior and Clarence follow. cUuT TO
Rocky, Junior and Clarence move down the block. Rocky seems to be looking for something.
They all look the same to me.

We need the right house. We need money, and we need a car. ANGLE - HOUSES - PAN SHOT - ROCKY’S POV Rocky and Junior look at the houses and the camera linger at the Brady house. It seems to have a faint glow around it, and the muted STRAINS OF THE "BRADY" THEME make it ev more obvious what their choice will be.
That’s the house, Junior.
You sure?
Sure, I’m sure. Whoever lives here has gotta have cars, and plenty of dough. Junior and Clarence follow as Rocky goes down the drivewa and into the backyard.
They pause at the garage and look inside.

(whispering) Six bicycles? Six kids? They gotta be crazy. Rocky and Junior move to the far side of the backyard and case the joint. Clarence hangs back, as a lookout, listening for any unusual sounds.
(continuing) This place is perfect....We’1ll hang out til morning. After the kids go to school, we’1l move in, take some money, some clothes, grab a car and get out.
The Bradys’ sheepdog, Tiger, comes out of his doghouse, sees the two intruders and starts barking. Rocky raises a gun, and aims it at Tiger. Junior pulls his arm down.

Dad, it’s just a dog. Tiger ignores the warning and keeps barking. cuT TO INT. MIKE AND CAROL’S BEDROOM Mike and Carol hear Tiger and wake up. They turn on the lamps on the nightstands. Both of their bathrobes are carefully laid out on the foot of his bed.
Mike, is that Tiger?
It must be. That’s the only dog we’ve got.
Want to go see what’s bothering him?
Obeying her suggestion, he gets out of bed, puts on one sleeve of his robe, then thinks better of it.
Why don’t we give it a minute? Chances are Tiger just saw a squirrel or something.
Tiger is still holding Rocky, Junior and Clarence at bay.
People would hear a shot, Dad. Some food would keep him quiet.
Hey, we got better thar food. With that, Rocky takes a beer can, pops the top, and pour some in Tiger’s water dish. Tiger immediately shuts up, laps up the lager and hiccups.
INT. MIKE AND CAROL’S BEDROOM - ANGLE - MIKE He reacts to the fact that Tiger stopped barking.

See? I told you it was nothing. (then, romantically) . But as long as Tiger woke us up -- Mike starts to take off his robe, then hops into bed. He eases over toward Carol’s side, then reacts as he sees Carol is fast asleep. He shrugs, and prepares for a less active night.
MUSIC: (“EVERYTHING IS BEAUTIFUL" ~ RAY STEVENS OR

AS CAMERA SURVEYS the room. As ‘seen in the first scene, each wall area is individualized for the child sleeping in the bed underneath it. Cindy has the pretty picture of a cat. Marcia has a picture of Darryl, and Jan has an evil punk rock poster. SLOW PAN of the sleeping girls. Cindy is sleeping with her favorite doll, Kitty Karry-All Marcia has an angelic smile. When the camera reaches Jan, her eyes are open. She has a diabolical look and quietly sneaks out of bed. She crosses to the desk and removes a pair of wicked looking scissors. She skulks back to the sleeping Marcia. Jan takes the scissors and -- miraculously without waking Marcia -- cuts away at her older sister’s long blonde hair.
Cindy awakens, and sees Jan hovering "Norman Bates-like" over Marcia.
(in a horrified whisper) Jan, what are you doing?
As Jan continues to cut Marcia’s locks...
Something I should have done a long time ago.
You shouldn’t do that to Marcia. She’s so pretty.
Yeah? Well, I’m a little sick of everybody telling me how pretty Marcia is.
Stop it. Stop it right now.

You know something? You really bug me, too. Jan crosses quickly to Cindy and -- with a well-timed sni -- clips off one of Cindy’s pigtails. Twirling it like a trophy she hops back to her bed and settles down victoriously.

Jan, no! Jan, no! Cindy screams. This wakes up the shorn Marcia who feels her head and crosses to the mirror. She screams in anguish. Now Marcia and Cindy are both screaming and Jan is smiling. Finally...
Jan! Jan!
With a contented smile, Jan is blissfully asleep.
(continuing) Jan! Jan, wake up, for school.
WE PULL BACK and discover it was.all a dream. Both Marcia and Cindy have all their hair. dan looks at both of them.
Darn it.
What’s the matter?
I was just dreaming.
Was it a nightmare?
No. Best dream I ever had. _As Jan gets out of bed and heads for the bathroom...
(continuing) Greg, Peter, Bobby...You better not be in there. I’ve got to go. She enters. cut To  17

Taking up a good portion of the wall is the activity char Each of the kids has a column, and written in is the day’ activities. On Sunday, church is for each, but the other days have cheerleading practice, Little League, football practice, glee club, drama class, Sunflower Girls, Fronti Scouts, etc., etc. PULL BACK TO find Alice making breakfast. She has a plate of hotcakes and puts them on the table. She whistles her Alice whistle.
Hotcakes, everybody! Alice then steps to the entranceway to the kitchen, and awaits the thundering herd. Peter is first.
(continuing) You/re always first, Peter.
I like to get ‘em when they’re hot. He sits down and starts to eat immediately.
Now, everyone else enters the kitchen, and takes their places at the table.
I’ve got hotcakes for everyone -- that is if Peter decides to leave you any.
No hotcakes for me, Alice. I’m watching my figure.
Me, too.
Me, too.
Jan, don’t you think you should have a figure before you start watching it?
Thanks, Alice. That’s just what I needed.
How’s rehearsal going, gang?
Real groovy, Dad.
Yeah. And if we win the big amateur night contest, we’ll be able to --
As Greg kicks Cindy’s foot.
You’1l be able to what?
(trying to cover) We’ll be able to win. Like you always say, Dad. “There’s more to winning than coming in first."
Well put, Greg.
Are you going to rehearse this afternoon?
Not today. I’ve got football practice.
I’ve got cheerleading practice.
I’ve got detention.
I’m bringing in my volcano for the science fair. I’m hoping for a major eruption.
Then you better rehearse your number tomorrow before the show.
My Sunflower Girl troop is meeting here.
I’ve got my Little League Game.
You know, kids, Stephen MacKenna once said, “All good is gained by those whose thoughts and life are kept pointed to “one main thing, not scattered abroad upon a thousand"...
As they react to this philosophy.
Who’s Stephen MacKenna?-
Someone very famous, Bobby. You know your father only quotes very famous people.
While you‘re doing all these things, the other acts will be rehearsing.
Thank goodness we’re very talented. GREG . We'll rehearse tonight, Dad. After dinner.
He is watching the TV on the counter.
Hey, look at this. A couple of guys escaped from prison by digging under the wall.  20
Right on.
"Right on?" When they get caught, they’11l lose any chance of parole.

Rocky Portugal and Clarence Dawkins are believed to be in the Santa Monica area. Portugal is a male Caucasion, and has a distinctive tattoo with the numbers 1-2-3 on his right hand. Dawkins is a large Black man, with a scar on his left cheek. On the screen is a picture of Rocky, and then one of Clarence.

In other news, some survivors of the air crash in the Andes: Mountains admit to eating other victims who had frozen. They say it was only as a last resort but that their friends tasted kind of like --
Carol quickly turns off the TV so the children won’t hear the rest of the report.
How gross.
I think it’s neat. Marcia, wouldn’t you rather eat Cindy than die?
Mom, tell Jan to stop.
Jan, it’s not nice to talk about eating your sister.
Your mother’s right. Not at breakfast anyway. Mike looks at his watch and realizes he’s late.
(continuing) Got to run. The big Riverside project. CAROL . We‘ve all got to go. Let’s head them up and move them out.

All right. All luncheaters line up. The kids get ina line, and Alice grabs a lunch at a time and like a pitching machine delivers it to the proper child. Bobby and Cindy are the only ones with lunch boxes

I‘ll be home this afternoon, Alice. I’ve got my anti-smoking committee or my anti-grafitti committee. I’m not sure exactly, but I know it’s my anti- -something committee. The family all adlib good-byes to ) Alice and leaves. The exit through the...
And cross through before exiting into...

The Brady family crosses to the two cars. Mike takes Greg and Marcia. Carol takes Peter, Jan, Bobby and Cindy. They buckle their seat belts and drive out, and WE PAN to the edge of the garage where Rocky and Junior step out.
There really are six kids. What were they thinking?
Okay. Everybody's gone. Let’s get in, and get out.
That’s my boy. But first... Rocky adds a little more beer to Tiger’s water dish. Tiger immediately starts to lap it up. Then Rocky and Junior move to the family room door and enter.  22

Alice finishes clearing the table and goes into her room. Just as she exits, Rocky and Junior enter the kitchen. A near miss. They stop to munch on a few leftover hotcakes. They think they’re alone in the house now. Rocky looks around critically. i

An orange kitchen? How can anybody eat in here? cuT To INT. ALICE’S BEDROOM A spartan maid’s room with a smiling picture of Sam tucke into the mirror. Also, a picture of Alice with the Brady family on the dresser. Alice enters and goes to her phone on the nightstand. She starts to dial.
INT. SAM’S BUTCHER SHOP SAM, the butcher and Alice’s longtime boyfriend, is helpi a customer, MRS. STONE, in his small establishment.
Are these lamb chops fresh, Mrs. Stone? Last night while I was sleeping, I counted them jumping over the fence. Sam laughs at his own joke.
Sam, you’re lucky. The meat is always fresher than your jokes.
(laughing) That will be six-fifty. Sam takes the money as the phone rings. He answers it as the customer exits.
INT. ALICE’S BEDROOM
Hiya, Alice. What can I do for my girl this morning?
I just called to remind you about tomorrow night.
No need to remind me. 1/11 be there with my bowling ball and my 136 average.
Sam, nobody bowls at the Hollywood Bowl. The kids are competing in the finals of the amateur contest.
I know, but Alice, what about my team? You don’t want me to let down the Bowling Butchers.
(sarcastically) Of course not, Sam.

Oh, Alice. That’s not.fair. I went to see Marcia in Romeo-and Juliet; I went to see the Bradys in the school talent show. Heck, I even acted in Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs. I’ve got my own life, too, Alice. The whole world doesn’t revolve around the Bradys.
Fine, Sam. And you know what you can do with your bowling ball. She hangs up.
Rocky and Junior are eating the last of the leftover breakfast food. CAMERA FOLLOWS them as they exit the kitchen and cross into the living roon.
Hey, look at this place! Some of this stuff could be worth a fortune. Clarence picks up the ceramic horse. Rocky taps it.
(continuing, disgusted) Plaster of paris. Junk.
Junior picks up "the vase".
Maybe this is worth something. Junior examines it.
(continuing) No. It’s broken, and glued back together.
The only thing I hate worse than rich guys is cheap rich guys. He smashes the vase for spite. Rocky leads the others toward the stairs.

(continues) While we're waiting for Mom to come back with the car, let’s scope out the rest of the place. ae As soon as they disappear around the upstairs hallway, Alice enters with a dust rag. She finds the pieces of the vase, shakes her head.

Peter, you’re in trouble again. She puts the pieces back together and moves up the stairway, dusting the banister on her way up. INT. MIKE AND CAROL’S BEDROOM Rocky is opening all the drawers. He looks through a jewelry box, finds several gold chains. He hands them to Clarence, who bites on them, and shakes his head.
The guy is too cheap to buy his wife real gold. He’s keeping it all in cash someplace.
Why don’t we just grab a car and go? Why do we need so much money?
Clarence has some friends who can make us some fake I.D.’s and passports, so we can get out of the country.
ved
They want cash.
Some world. Nobody trusts anybody. : Rocky pulls the cover off the bed and checks under the mattress. They find nothing very valuable. He looks in Mike’s closet, pulls out some drab sports jackets.
One thing for sure, the clown’s not spending it on clothes. He throws the clothes down.
Maybe he’s hiding it in some other room.
Come on. All three exit Mike and Carol’s bedroom and enter the upstairs hallway.

They walk toward the girls’ bedroom. As soon as they pass the walk-in linen closet, Alice exits into the hallway wi an armload of towels and sheets. She doesn’t see then; nor they her. They enter the girls’ bedroom. Alice enters Mike and Carol’s bedroom. INT. MIKE AND CAROL’S BEDROOM Alice puts her load down on the bureau and looks at the mess that Rocky has made.

Mr. and Mrs. Brady never left their room like this before. Maybe they really got into it. Maybe Mr. Brady tore off her clothes, and threw her on the floor and -- (reacts) Mr. and Mrs. Brady??? Nahhh!!... She shakes her head and goes to work straightening up.  ees 27 INT. GIRLS’ BEDROOM | Alice freezes as she hears the toy from the other room.

"A duck goes quack, quack." Alice looks around for a weapon in the girl’s bedroom. All she can find is an umbrella with a 60’s flower design Scared, but determined, she starts through the bathroom to the boys’ bedroom. She knocks} into the desk as she goes. INT. BOYS’ BEDROOM Rocky freezes as he hears the noise from the boys’ bedroo
(whispering) We've got company. (then loudly) We've got guns!
INT. BATHROOM oy Alice is terrified. She opens the umbrella.
Yeah? Well, I’ve got an umbrella. With that, she realizes the folly|of her position and run out the door.
Alice races for the stairway. Rocky, Junior and Clarence enter the hallway and follow her.

_In a desperate effort to escape, Alice slides down the banister. As she does, the umbrella pops open. Junior and Clarence follow as each slides down the banister and cut her off as Rocky points his gun at her as he walks do the stairs.
Hold it right there, Mary Poppins. Alice stops in her tracks as. she gets to the living room Rocky, Junior and Clarence join her.
(nervously) You’re not going to do anything to me, are you? Rocky looks at her -- not exactly his type of woman.
Are you serious? I was only in prison three years. |
What do you want?
We want some money.
If you know what’s good for you, you better take us to the money.
I don’t know where it is. I’m only the housekeeper. Mr. and Mrs. Brady? I hardly know them. Heck, I can’t even keep the kids straight.;, Greg, Marcia, Happy, Bashful, Dopey, Prancer, Donner, Blitzen?
Have they got a safe?
How should I know? Rocky makes a more threatening gesture with his gun. Alic gives in.

(continuing) Right this way. Alice leads them back up the stairs and through the hallway. INT. MIKE AND CAROLS’ BEDROOM They enter. Alice crosses to the dresser. Over the dresser is a large portrait of the Bradys, the one along the stairs. Alice swings the portrait away from the wall to reveal a wall safe. Junior looks at Mike’s architectur degree on the wall.
nal 29
Now that’s more like it. What’s the combination?
I don’t know. Rocky menaces her with the gun again.

+ (continuing) Honest, I don’t know. I’m just the housekeeper. Why else would I wear this dumb blue uniform? Think about it. Would you tell your housekeeper the combination to your safe? I could be a crook or something. (realizing) Not that I have anything against crooks. Junior indicates the framed degree.
They got to have money: . The guy’s an architect.
Too bad the safe won’t open. I guess you’ll be running along, huh?
Bad guess. We're going to wait for Mr. and Mrs.....
Brady.
Right. Brady.
They’re not expected home for a long long time.
Then it will be a long long wait. cuT TO

Marcia, the head cheerleader (What else?) is leading the CHEERLEADING SQUAD in a B - E ~ A - R - S cheer with a lo of kicking and pompoming. All are real cute. MISS STANDFAST, the cheerleading advisor comes over to the girls.

Now, girls, that was very good. But if you all pay attention to Marcia, you’1l1 see how to do it exactly right. Marcia? Marcia does it again, but adds an incredible flourish wit a handspring and a cartwheel.
They react. No way can they do what Marcia did. One of them raises her hand. at WENDY . Miss Standfast, do we have to do that stuff at the end?
No, Wendy. Nobody can do that, except for Marcia... and, of course, me in my day.
She smiles and combs her long blonde hair.
Come. on. Let’s go check out Greg Brady. The girls move over to watch football practice. cuT TO

THE WESTDALE FOOTBALL TEAM is exercising on the field. Greg is the halfback and listening to the COACH who is outlining the play to the OFFENSE. The DEFENSE waits for the offense to come to the line of scrimmage.

Okay, men, this is Red B eleven. We’re going to need this in the opener against the Razorbacks. Taylor, you fake the . handoff to Brady. Roll to your right. Brady blocks the defensive end and you complete to Petrie cutting across. Okay, men. Hit it. The offense claps and moves to the line of scrimmage.
Taylor, the quarterback, executes the play perfectly. It picks up twelve against the defense. The backfield regroups around the coach.

Once we run this, they’1ll be looking for it. From the same.'formation, Taylor will fake the ball to Brady again, Petrie you do your thing across the middle, but Brady will drift into the flat and get a quick pass from Taylor. Brady should have a clear path up the sideline. It’s Blue B eleven. Hit it.

They clap again and hit the line of scrimmage. The play works. Greg blocks, then drifts, takes the pass and does a nifty run for a touchdown against the defensive tean.. After Greg spirals the ball back to the quarterback, he is surrounded by the three pretty cheerleaders.
Well, Greg, all ready for the Razorbacks next weekend?
Sure am.

Rocky hears this and...
Turn it up louder. Peter does so. All activity stops as they all crowd in to watch the TV.

Police have announced in Santa Monica that’ they found the burned remains of the car belonging to Portugal’s son, Junior. Both Portugals and Clarence Dawkins are considered armed and dangerous and are believed to be in the local area. Use extreme caution. In other news, actress Elizabeth Taylor marries for the fifth time and swears this time it’s going to last. Rocky turns off the TV and turns to Junior.
I told you using your car was dumb.
Sorry, Dad.

A lot of good "sorry" does. (to Mike) Kids drive you nuts. They just can’t learn how to do things right. THE PHONE RINGS. Carol goes to answer it. Rocky is immediately on alert. He follows her to the phone.
Hello.

Indeed, it is a vast dirt area near a riverside. The foundation has already been dug and large construction tractors are standing by for the next phase. MR. PHILLIPS Mike’s boss, is there with TWO BUSINESSMEN. He is using a construction crew phone and is angry. .
Carol, this is Harry Phillips.
Oh, hi, Mr. Phillips.
Where exactly is your husband? Carol is very nervous, but tries to remain calm.
He‘s here.
That‘s the problem. He’s supposed to be here.
I better let him explain.
If that’s possible. Mike takes a breath and takes the phone. Rocky is nearby, gun poised.
Hi, Mr. Phillips.
Brady, do you know what you’re doing at home? You are risking blowing this whole deal. This multimillion dollar eal.
(on the phone) I realize that, but...
Get down here right away. Mike turns to Rocky, desperately upset.
He wants me to go down there right away.
Tell him you can’t.
But he’s my boss. What can I say?
Try "something suddenly came up." It always works for me. Like when I want to break a date.
(interrupting) Not now, honey.
Rocky now
(forcefully) Tell him.
(on the phone) Believe me, Mr. Phillips, I’d really like to be there with you, but "something suddenly came up" --
What?! Our whole company’s future rests on this project, and you say something suddenly came up?!
(on the phone) Yes, that’s what I’m saying. enjoys the position he’s putting Mike in.
Tell him you're sick of him and his whole small time company.
But...
(waving his gun) Tell him.
(on the phone) Please accept this in a positive way, Mr. Phillips, but I’m sick of you ang your whole small time company.
Brady, I was thinking of making you a partner. Now, if I can do it legally, I‘1ll have your license revoked as an architect.
(on the phone) Mr. Phillips, please don’t --
(loving this) Call him a rotten scum-bucket.
(horrified) I can’t. Rocky holds a gun up to Carol.
Call him a rotten scum-bucket, or I/11 kill your wife. Mike sees he has absolutely no alternative.
(weakly) Mr. Phillips, one more thing. (practically sobbing) You’re a rotten scum-bucket. Phillips hangs up, turns to the waiting businessmen.
Gentlemen, there’s been a slight delay.
Mike is crushed as he hangs up the phone.

Mike, Junior, Peter, and Bobby are walking toward the res of Bobby’s team, THE ANGELS. Bobby is in uniform. Mike has an Angel shirt and cap. Junior wears a windbreaker and has a gun in his belt so the weapon won‘t be seen. Mike is still dazed from the events of the day. They pass a BAG LADY near a refreshment stand, with discarded items in a shopping cart.
(her hand out) Mr. Brady, you always have something for me.
(too occupied) Sorry. Not now.
You’ve got to forgive my father, Mr. Brady. He’s really not such a bad guy. He’s robbed stores and banks, but he’s never shot anybody yet.
He’s going to end up back in prison. You know that, don’t you?
He’s had a tough life. His parents never wanted him. Reform school when he was thirteen.
What about your life? Are you ready to see that flushed away, too? If you stick with him ~~
Sorry, Mr. Brady. But my father is my father, and that’s it. (patting the gun)..: You guys try anything,. and it’s over. Got it?
Yeah. We/’ve got it. Mike, Peter, Bobby and Junior reach the stands where OTHE PARENTS sit. Peter and Junior sit as Mike and Bobby head to the field. cut TO
Carol, Alice, Marcia, Jan and Cindy wait uneasily as Rock and Greg approach Carol.
Mom, Greg and me are going to run an errand. CAROL . ; What? Greg, you’re not leaving us in the house with this man. (indicates Clarence)
Don’t worry about Clarence, unless you try something stupid.
Mom, we’ll be back in an hour.

Just remember... (to Clarence) Clarence... Taking the cue from Rocky, Clarence picks up the ceramic horse, and smashes it against his head. Greg and Rocky exit, and Carol, Alice and the three girls are impressed and terrified by the impassive Clarence.
BELLINGHAM, the umpire, a gruff no-nonsense sort, is filling in his line-up sheet.
Mike is desperately trying to come up with a way to save his family when he sees the Umpire. He gets an idea, and crosses to Bobby.
Bobby, that umpire is Bellingham, isn’t it?
Sure is, Dad. Toughest in the league.
He's an ex-cop, isn’t he?
Hey, that’s right. Mike has suddenly discovered a plan to help his family.

With Clarence observing the proceedings, the room is now filled with Sunflower Girls and Sunflower Girls’ Mothers. All are standing in a circle. All the little girls are in uniform -- including Cindy -- and are singing "The Sunflower Girl Song".

"I’m glad to be a Sunflower Girl, I wear my banner proud, If someone needs my help one day, I‘ll help if I’m allowed. Sunflower Girls are filled with love, They-shine both night and day, I’ll live my life the best I can And‘ live it the Sunflower way. I’1l live my life the whole whole while, Smiling the Sunflower smile."
He watches, and shows no emotion.
They are off to one side and looking for an opportunity to somehow end their captivity.
Carol is the leader.
Very good, Sunflower Girls. First I’m sure we’d all like to give a big Sunflower Girl hello to Cindy’s sisters and former Sunflower Girls, Marcia and Jan.
Hello, Marcia, and Jan!
And also we’re very lucky to have another guest today. our old family friend... (at a loss, looks to Clarence)
(quickly) Kareem.
Everyone looks at Clarence. ANGLE - CLARENCE - GROUP’S POV He gives a reluctant wave.
So can we have a big Sunflower Girl "Hello Kareem"?
Hello, Kareem. Embarrassed and awkward, Clarence nods. cuT TO

Greg and Rocky pull up to a corner in the Brady station wagon. Wendy, Betsy, and Kimberly are waiting -- no longe in cheerleader outfits. They jump into the back seat, but they are concerned when they see Rocky.
Who's your friend, Greg? Nobody’s supposed to know about this.
Don’t worry. Uncle Jerry is cool.
Did you tell him what we’re doing?
Yeah, and he’s going to help us.
That’s great. WENDY . Last year, Greg stole the school mascot from Coolidge High before the big game. It was a goat.
This year we’re helping him steal the mascot from Ridgewood.
It’s a razorback.
Uncle Jerry thinks it’s a great idea.
(to Rocky) You think it’s okay to steal a mascot.
I think it’s okay to steal anything... as long as you have a good reason. The girls laugh.
Peter and Junior are really hitting it off quite well.
You know something, Junior, it’s not the prize itself that’s so important.
You mean the contest at The Hollywood Bowl?
Yeah. This is Mom and Dad’s fifth anniversary. And the prize is perfect for them.
Fifth anniversary? You got six kids, and the youngest is eight.
Well, she’s not my real: mom.
She’s not?
It’s a long story. She was a lovely lady who was bringing up three very lovely girls --
And what happened?
Well, one day this lady met a fellow, who was busy with three boys of his own. That’s how we became the Brady Bunch.
The Brady Bunch?
Yeah. That’s how we all hecame the Brady Bunch. cuT TO
The Sunflower Girls and mother are all playing the memory game. A plump Sunflower Girl, OLIVIA, sits next to Clarence and is reciting...
I went to the zoo and I saw a monkey, an elephant, a rhinocerous, a giraffe with a long neck. ~ (adding her own) .»..and a camel with two humps.
Good. Who’s next?
I’m next. I went to the zoo, and I saw a monkey, an elephant, a rhinocerous, a giraffe with a long neck... a camel with two humps... (adds her own) ».,and a great big tiger...
Good, Laurie. Who’s next?
How about Kareem? All eyes turn to Clarence.
Me?
Sure. All new guests have to play. It’s the Sunflower Girls way of making you feel welcome.
(uncertainly) Well...
Kareem should play? Right, Sunflower Girls? The Sunflower Girls all adlib agreement. Cindy is forced to appeal to hin.
(reluctantly) Please, Kareen. Clarence gives in to the pressure.

(awkwardly) I went to the zoo and I saw a monkey, an elephant, a rhinocerous, a giraffe with a long neck... a camel with two humps... a great big tiger... (adds his own) : ..-And a black and white zebra, all locked in their cells. (then) I mean, cages. A lot of innocent animals in cages. The others all are puzzled by this as we: cuT TO

Greg, Rocky, and the three pom pom girls pull up in the station wagon next to the gym. Painted boldly on a sign on a chain link fence: It’s a cartoon of a razorback. ANGLE - GREG’S POV The gym is behind a locked chain link fence and a STUDENT GUARD is a posted sentry.
That’s what I heard. They’re guarding the razorback.
Probably because of what you did last year.
BETSY s Check out that big lock. i
Don’t worry, girls. Leave it to Uncle - Jerry. cUuT TO
The plywood platform is pushed to the side. The Sunflower Girls are lined up for a three legged race.
The winners get to take home the extra chocolate chip cookies.
Alice can be seen baking cookies through the screen.
They can practically smell the cookies from the backyard. Talk about incentive.
The Olivia team is leading. Various mothers root for thei daughters.
He’s an observer, on the watch for any false moves, and is starting to smile more and more.
The Olivia team wins! Clarence is happier than anybody.
Bobby is on the mound. Bases are loaded. He throws a wild pitch.
nae 79
BELLINGHAM’ : Ball four. Take your base. The batter goes to first. A run walks in. The next batter strides confidently to the plate. Bobby winds up and throws a pitch that soars over the backstop.
The ball smashes into a pyramid display of soft drink can and knocks them all over.
(continuing) Time out. The Umpire walks out to the mound, and signals for Mike to come from the dugout. BELLINGHAM.’ (continuing) Brady, get your kid out: of here before he kills somebody.
You’re an ex-cop, right? I need help.
Your pitcher is the one who needs help. Mike looks toward the stands. ANGLE - PETER AND JUNIOR - MIKE’S POV Junior senses something fishy, and stares at Mike.
(quickly) It’s a matter of life and death.
Get somebody else out here, or it will be. Mike knows he can’t stay any longer. He signals to the shortstop to take over. Mike returns to the dugout. cuT TO  80
Greg enters, and stops at the chain link fence to talk to the Student Guard.
How’s it going?
(instantly suspicious) Hey, you’re Greg Brady. You’re the guy who stole the mascot from Coolidge High. Greg sees the padlock and fiddles with it.
Wow! You’re making sure nobody steals this mascot?
That’s right. I suggest you get lost. Right now.
The three girls swoop in, and elirtatiously get close to the Student Guard.
Hiya, cutie.
I‘m surprised you’re not on the football team instead of guarding the mascot.
Okay, okay. I know you girls. You’re the cheerleaders his team.
Come on, girls, we’ll never get past this guy. But before they can take a step away...
He comes up to the mascot guard.
Good work, son. (to Greg and the girls) You kids get moving.
ad 81
Greg and the Cheerleaders exit.
What’s your name, son?
Chuck Alpert.
I’m proud of you, Chuck. I think you saved the Ridgewood mascot for the big game.
Thanks.

Get up the administration building, and bring back form 862. That’s a special commendation. I want to reward you for excellent work. 1/11 take care of things until you get back. Immediately, the Student Guard steps away from the fenced area, and hurries off.
(quickly) . I’ve got to tell you something about my Uncle Jerry, he’s --
(interrupts) He’s the best. None of my relatives would ever ‘help me steal anything.
But there’s something more important.
Yeah, we got to get out of here.
(desperately) Listen -- But the three girls hurry to join Rocky at the locked gat Greg has no alternative but to follow.
non! 82
Rocky takes a hairpin from one of the cheerleader’s hair, and quickly picks the padlock. They all enter the fenced area, then enter the building.

Greg and Rocky, and the Cheerleaders like a commando unit approach the cage which holds the razorback. Greg takes a rope from his jacket pocket, and opens the cage. He gingerly ties the rope around the animal’s neck, and brin it out of its cage.
Watch out for their tusks. They charge at you, and they’re vicious. The Cheerleaders make appropriately squeamish sounds, but happily join Greg and Rocky as they take their ‘conquest out of the gym.
Mike, Peter, Bobby and Junior are leaving. The four pass the refreshment stand where they had passed the Bag Lady when they entered. She puts her hand out to Mike again.
How about now?
(curtly) Not now. They walk off.
She gives the Italian "up yours" gesture. a cuT TO
Greg drives up with Rocky, and the razorback. The razorback is squealing.
Greg and Rocky enter the garage, and as Greg ties the razorback to the leg of a workbench with the leash...
GREG ‘ I’ve gotta hide the razorback in the garage so my folks won’t see hin.
Greg and Rocky exit, and head for the backyard and the Sunflower Girls meeting.
The Sunflower Girls meeting: girls, mothers and Clarence.
They enter the backyard. Rocky crosses the yard, and sees a basket on the barbecue. The basket is marked: "Sunflower Girl Dues". He quickly helps himself to the money, and puts it in his pocket.
She sees what Rocky has done, and crosses to him.
How can you do that? That money belongs to the Sunflower Girls.
So what. Money is money. Jan glares at hin.
He crosses to Carol.
Are you okay, Greg?
Everything’s fine, Mom. Carol moves to rejoin her guests as Jan talks to Greg and Marcia.  84
Kareem, it was a pleasure meeting you. Some men just have a way with children.
They’ve only got one gun now. I’ve got a plan how we can take these guys.
Count me in.
It’s a football play. Listen. As Greg whispers to Marcia and Jan: cuT TO

Carol, Cindy, and Alice are ushering the mothers and Sunflower Girls, who are leaving. Charlotte and Doris are leading their children. Olivia is munching on a cookie. Rocky crosses to Clarence, who is also eating a cookie.
I knew Olivia would win. She loves cookies.
Wait a minute! There’s paper in this cookie!

You were supposed to wait until you got home to eat those. . Olivia starts to spit out the offending cookie with the paper. Quickly, Rocky moves to take the slip of paper awa - from Olivia. He looks at it. ‘ ROCKY . Hmmm. . (meaningfully) Alice should have been more careful. As the girls and their mothers look at this new stranger.
(continuing) Hello, everybody. I’m Uncle Jerry.
(to Carol) We had a wonderful time, Carol. And Kareem should visit more often.
Thank you. None the wiser, the Sunflower Girls and mothers exit.
Rocky opens the soggy paper. He reads it aloud.
"Kareem is an escaped convict. Call the police." (then) Some fortune cookie.
Jan and Marcia are ready. -
Hey, Rocky...
What?
I don’t think you're so tough! I think you’d make a real cute Sunflower Girl.

Hey, don’t get me mad. Just because you’re a kid that don’t mean you’re safe. Rocky pulls out the gun and starts to rush the stairs. Greg -- according to plan -- blocks him. Marcia does a cheerleader flip down the stairs and ends with a cartwhee in which she knocks the gun from Rocky’s hand. The gun flies through the air and lands at Cindy’s feet.
Ne 86
Carol, Alice, Greg, Marcia, Jan; ‘Cindy, Rocky, and Clarence. The moment is frozen in time. All Cindy has to do is pick up the gun.
Cindy, pick up the gun. Pick up the | gun, sweetheart. Instead, Cindy screams. This gives Rocky the time he need to grab the gun and resume command.
Nice try, kids.
Mike, Peter, Bobby, and Junior return from the game. The Brady men are depressed.
(down) Hi, Honey. We/’re home.
How’d you do, Bobby?
We lost.
So’d we.
Tiger bounds in and scratches at Junior’s leg.
Fill him up. Junior follows the happy Tiger into the kitchen to give him some more beer. Rocky waves his gun to Mike’s group on the landing.
(to Mike) While you were away, Pop, I had a little _. trouble with your family. Mike comes to Carol immediately.
Is everybody okay, honey?
Yeah, they’re okay, but they gave me ~- trouble. And I don’t like trouble. (calling to Junior) How’d you make out at the game?
As Junior pours beer for Tiger who laps it up enthusiastically.
(calling back) No problem, but Mr. Brady doesn’t know diddly about baseball. Junior returns to the living room.
Look, we gotta stay here till Monday, and you guys gotta behave yourselves. The Bradys all nod agreement.
(continuing) Until then, we’re gonna stick close to you. Including the Hollywood Bowl.
You can’t do that. We’re going to be on stage. .
Everyone will see you.
You'll get identified.
I got it all worked out. Whose wig is that in the girl’s bedroom?
What wig?
It’s mine. The one I wore when I didn’t want blonde hair like Marcia and Cindy.
aed 88
I thought you got rid of that.
(snapping) I didn’t. Okay?
Clarence stays here with Mom. If anything goes wrong at the Bowl, Clarence knows what to do. Clarence nods.
On stage in the middle of the classic aria from "Madame Butterfly" is a distinguished elderly woman, MARJORIE LEWENDOWSKI. She is very good. ~

The Brady kids are gathered before they go on. The kids wear the hippest 70’s singing group outfits, the girls in mini-skirts. They are nervous for a lot of reasons. Rocky is with them. He wears Jan’s black wig. He’s wearing one of Mike’s fancy sport shirts, open in a large "Vv" to rev several gold chains around his neck. He’s also wearing dark glasses. The hand with the tattoo is in his pocket, accompanied by the ever-present gun. The EMCEE of the event, in tuxedo, approaches.
Ready to go on, kids? “GREG Yeah.
{to Rocky) Who are you?
Tell ‘im, Greg.
(reluctantly, to Emcee) Mr. Jones, this is our manager. Okay if he stays in the wings?
Sure. Good luck, kids. Rocky stays in the wings where he can keep an eye on the kids. Meanwhile, the kids gather together.
(sotto) Have you got the new lyrics?
(sotto) Right. ANGLE - THE STAGE “ Marjorie, the opera singer, finishes the number to enormo applause.
Packed. A classic observance of early 1970’s mood and wardrobe. Polyester clothes, long sideburns, beehive hairstyles, etc.
The Emcee goes to the microphone.
The next act is a real crowd pleaser: Patty’s Prancing Poodles. As barking is heard... cur TO
Carol and Clarence are not saying anything. Finally...
Clarence, you were very good with the i children today.
That’s what that lady said. I never had much to do with kids before.
Maybe you should be working with children.
I don’t know. Being a crook. is the only job I ever had. cuT TO
The razorback gnaws and gnaws at the rope -- then with a yank, breaks free, and starts out of the garage.
The last act is a group of youngsters who call themselves: The Silver Platters. The Brady kids run out on stage. They get set as the INTR
It’s Darryl and Sam. They didn’t come together. They just happen to be sitting next to one another.
(recognizing Darryl) | Hey, you’re Marcia’s boyfriend, aren’t you?
I was Marcia’s boyfriend. Aren’t you Alice’s boyfriend?
I was Alice’s boyfriend. But I’m just leftovers now. What are you doing here?
I just came to look at Marcia. Even if I can’t feel her up, at least I can look at her.
"The Silver Platters" start to sing.
Mike, Alice, Rocky and Junior in the wings. Sam and Darry in the audience. The Emcee, etc. But:
_ When Greg and Marcia distinctly.change the lyrics.

ALL: Let me hear some of that good time music, That I love to hear. GREG: © I’ve got plenty of blues, MARCIA: And sort of bad news, GREG/MARCIA: And I need to find me some cheer. - MARCIA: Well, there’ve been some times, When I’ve been down, ° More so recently. GREG: I’ve run clear out of fun I’m under the gun. . GREG/MARCIA: Can’t you all see? ALL: There’s no sense in walking around, With your feet stuck in the ground. MARCIA: Try to envision “y Getting out of prison teing out of prison. NN _ GREG: Create a lot of love and good vibes, For humanity.

92 That’s fine with me: Let me hear some of that good time music, That I love to hear. I’ve got plenty of blues, And sort of bad news, And I need to find me some cheer. Well, there’ve been some times, When I’ve been down, More so recently. Let_me confide T7ve had a rocky ride, Can ‘t you all see? There’s no sense in walking around, With your feet stuck in the ground. ps to escape, nd_get into shape... Create a lot of love and good vibes, For humanity.
That’s fine with me. Good time music. Good time music. Good time music. Good time music.
They love the song and applaud loudly.
Darryl is practically crying.
It’s okay, kid.
Did you see her legs, Sam? Marcia sure can sing.  93
Weren’t they great, folks? More applause from the audience,
(continuing) In a moment we’ll have the decision from the judges. cur TO
Carol is showing Clarence pictures in a family albun.
You really want to see the family pictures?
Yeah, I was never really part of any family.
These are pictures of Marcia when she was really little, and --
The razorback has. gotten into the house somehow, and is running into the living room. Carol and Clarence both react. Carol screams.
What the hell is that?
Greg must have stolen another school mascot. The razorback dashes across the living room, and starts running up the stairs. Clarence chases after it.
(to Carol) You stay put.
She remains seated.  we 94
A moment later the razorback comes back down stairs, followed by Clarence. The razorback dashes across the living room and into the kitchen. It is followed by Clarence.
Clarence enters. The razorback is snarling. Carol enters the kitchen, and cautiously moves to a cupboard. She retrieves a bottle of Wesson Oil.

This stuff is good for everything. She spills it onto the kitchen floor. The razorback start to charge Clarence, but its legs go out from under it. It slips and slides all around the kitchen. Carol gets a jump rope from the closet, and tosses it to Clarence.

Here. Clarence tries to do just that, but he, too, slips and slides on the oil. Carol seizes -this opportunity to try to escape. She starts toward the back door, but slips on the oil, too. In the ensuing slipping and sliding on the floor, the razorback’s tusk cuts Clarence’s hand. Carol sees this, and is torn between escaping and helping Clarence, who is bleeding.
The opera singer, Mike, Alice, Rocky, Junior, the Brady Kids, Patty and her Poodles, and two or three other contestants are waiting nervously.
An ASSISTANT crosses to the Emcee with a slip of paper.
This year’s runner up of the Los Angeles Parks and Recreation Amateur Competition is Patty’s Prancing Poodles.
Patty and her Prancing Poodles go out onto the stage.  95
Some people applaud.
The Emcee hands Patty a trophy. The dogs bark.
I hope the Bradys win.
The Bradys always win.
Patty and the dogs are gone now.
Look what the dogs did! Will somebody clean (eBent this stage? © e And the wianer of this ‘year’s Los Angeles Parks and Recreation Competition is The Silver Platters.
See!
The kids all jump up and down with excitement, as do Mike and Alice.
As they. all come out on stage and surround the Emcee.
You kids were just great, and here’s your prize. Two round trip tickets to Paris, France.
Applauding.  96
Two tickets for six kids. Who’s going to go?
Our parents. We wanted to win this for their wedding anniversary.
You’ve got two lucky parents. Let’s get them out on stage.
The Emcee assumes Alice is Mrs. Brady. He grabs them, and pulls them on stage.
Let’s hear it for this lucky couple with these six great kids. What a perfect pair! Don’t be shy. Give her a kiss. Mike shrugs, and kisses Alice.
Isn‘t that wonderful, folks? (applauds)
They applaud.
(desperately, whispers to Emcee) He Listen, you’ve got to help me. (pointing.to Rocky) That guy over there is --
(interrupting) I know. Their manager. And you’re right. He should be out here taking a bow, too. (calls) Come on out!
As he comes out on stage.  97
As they applaud.
Come on, kids, we've got contracts to sign, things to do. He grabs them, and hustles them and Mike and Alice, off stage. :
They begin to leave The Bowl.

head_text.subj: MIKE, ALICE, THE BRADY KIDS, ROCKY AND JUNIOR

text: They come down from the stage and start to exit with the audience.
As they approach our group. Darryl crosses to Marcia.
You were great! I knew you’d win, Marcia. MARCIA . Thanks, Darryl.
Alice, I just want to say I’m sorry. I gave up my bowling game to be here tonight, but I guess it’s too late.
Sorry, Sam. I understand how you feel, but what was important to you was your 123 average.
Marcia, I just want you to know I/11 always be there for you. I’m just sorry you like him -- i (indicating Junior) -- better than me.
Darryl, I’m afraid that’s the way it has to be. But at least -- (very dramatic) -- we'll always have the Junior Prom.
Rocky and Junior hustle the Bradys and Alice towards The Bowl exit, leaving Sam and Darryl.
They look at each other. Then... SAM . Looks like we’ve lost ‘em.
No way. Darryl quickly follows Junior and grabs him. Rocky sees this.
Buzz off, kid.
Marcia means too much to me.
Rocky and Junior are detained by Darryl. In the big crowd Mike sees an opportunity, and decides to go for it.
(to his family and Alice) Come on. Let’s go. They dash for the car.  99
Rocky and Junior see the Bradys running. They shake off Darryl, and start to follow them through the crowd. !
They reach the area marked "Contestant Cars", and start to get into their station wagon. Mike takes out his keys.
Dad, let me drive.
Greg, I drive a lot safer than you do.
I know, Dad. I know! Greg takes the keys. Mike lets him. They pile in, and screech away.

They can’t find a car with keys.» Then they are in luck. A lady (looking very much like Shirley Jones) is getting out of a psychedelically painted bus (looking very much like "The Partridge Family" transport). They grab her keys, and knock her out of the way.
Rocky is at the wheel as he and Junior pull out of the Bo parking lot to give chase. cuT TO
Let’s go to the police.
We don’t have time. Rocky and Junior will get to the house before we do, and we've got to save Mom. We have no idea what Clarence is up to. With this dire thought: cUT TO
Clarence has his arm on the table; and Carol is bandaging his bloody hand. Like Androcles and the Lion. The razorback is tied up in the corner. |
First time I ever saw a pig with tusks.
Does that feel better, Clarence?
Nobody’s ever done that before.
Bandaged your hand?
No. I’ve had lots of bandages. Heck, every time I get shot, I get a bandage.
Then what do you mean? CLARENCE . Nobody’s ever been nice to me before. cuT. TO
Greg looks in the rearview mirror.
Look at that!
Look at what?
The Partridge Family is gaining on us.
(taking a good look) That’s not the Partridge Family! It’s Rocky and Junior!
Incredible. For all intents and purposes, it’s the Partridge Family bus chasing the Brady station wagon.
They’‘ve got a bus. And all we have is , a car. iC This gives Greg an idea.
That’s right, Cindy. He quickly swerves into a closed car wash, and breaks through the chain.
Greg speeds through the wash which is big enough to allow acar, but not big enough for a bus. Rocky attempts to follow, but the bus is too wide, and gets wedged in the machinery.
The Bradys pull out of the car wash, and head home.
Greg speeds to a stop in front of the house. They all get out of the car, and move quickly to the front door.
Be quiet, and be careful.
